messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 55 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Recent Developments in Boolean Matrix Factorization1footnote 11footnote 1This technical report is the slightly extended version of a survey (Miettinen and Neumann, 2020) which appeared at IJCAI‚Äô20.

Paper Abstract: Abstract The goal of Boolean Matrix Factorization (BMF) is to approximate a given binary matrix as the product of two low-rank binary factor matrices, where the product of the factor matrices is computed under the Boolean algebra. While the problem is computationally hard, it is also attractive because the binary nature of the factor matrices makes them highly interpretable. In the last decade, BMF has received a considerable amount of attention in the data mining and formal concept analysis communities and, more recently, the machine learning and the theory communities also started studying BMF. In this survey, we give a concise summary of the efforts of all of these communities and raise some open questions which in our opinion require further investigation.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 55 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 55"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "A PTAS for ‚Ñìpsubscript‚Ñìùëù\\ell_{p}-low rank approximation",
        "From-below approximations in Boolean matrix factorization: Geometry and new algorithm",
        "A new algorithm for Boolean matrix factorization which admits overcovering",
        "Discovery of optimal factors in binary data via a novel method of matrix decomposition",
        "Streaming PTAS for binary ‚Ñì0subscript‚Ñì0\\ell_{0}‚Äìlow rank approximation",
        "On the parameterized complexity of biclique cover and partition",
        "1-bit matrix completion",
        "Co-clustering documents and words using bipartite spectral graph partitioning",
        "Fast exact and heuristic methods for role minimization problems",
        "Walk‚Äôn‚ÄôMerge: A scalable algorithm for Boolean tensor factorization",
        "Approximation schemes for low-rank binary matrix approximation problems",
        "Parameterized low-rank binary matrix approximation",
        "Two expectation-maximization algorithms for Boolean factor analysis",
        "Formal Concept Analysis: Mathematical Foundations",
        "Tiling databases",
        "Data reduction and exact algorithms for clique cover",
        "Identifying dynamics of brain function via Boolean matrix factorization",
        "BLASYS: approximate logic synthesis using Boolean matrix factorization",
        "C-SALT: Mining class-specific alterations in Boolean matrix factorization",
        "The PRIMPING routine‚ÄîTiling through proximal alternating linearized minimization",
        "The trustworthy pal: Controlling the false discovery rate in Boolean matrix factorization",
        "Getting to know the unknown unknowns: Destructive-noise resistant Boolean matrix factorization",
        "Boolean matrix theory and applications",
        "Summarizing network processes with network-constrained Boolean matrix factorization",
        "Faster algorithms for binary matrix factorization",
        "Noisy and incomplete boolean matrix factorization via expectation maximization",
        "BEM: Mining coregulation patterns in transcriptomics via Boolean matrix factorization",
        "A convex optimization framework for bi-clustering",
        "A unifying framework for mining approximate top-kùëòk binary patterns",
        "Matrix Decomposition Methods for Data Mining: Computational Complexity and Algorithms",
        "Boolean tensor factorizations",
        "On finding joint subspace Boolean matrix factorizations",
        "The discrete basis problem",
        "Recent developments in boolean matrix factorization",
        "MDL4BMF: Minimum description length for Boolean matrix factorization",
        "A survey of clique and biclique coverings and factorizations of (0,1)-matrices",
        "Improved clustering algorithms for the bipartite stochastic block model",
        "Bipartite stochastic block models with tiny clusters",
        "Biclustering and boolean matrix factorization in data streams",
        "Contentment in graph theory: Covering graphs with cliques",
        "Boolean matrix factorization and noisy completion via message passing",
        "Modeling by shortest data description",
        "Bayesian Boolean matrix factorisation",
        "Probabilistic Boolean tensor decomposition",
        "An interpretable latent variable model for attribute applicability in the Amazon catalogue",
        "A review on dimensionality reduction for multi-label classification",
        "Boolean matrix factorization meets consecutive ones property",
        "BMaD ‚Äì A Boolean matrix decomposition framework",
        "The role mining problem: Finding a minimal descriptive set of roles",
        "On the complexity and approximation of binary evidence in lifted inference",
        "Multi-label classification using Boolean matrix decomposition",
        "Jointly clustering rows and columns of binary matrices: Agorithms and trade-offs",
        "Bipartite graph partitioning and data clustering",
        "Optimal bipartite network clustering",
        "Analysis of spectral clustering algorithms for community detection: The general bipartite setting"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 55 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Recent Developments in Boolean Matrix Factorization1footnote 11footnote 1This technical report is the slightly extended version of a survey (Miettinen and Neumann, 2020) which appeared at IJCAI‚Äô20., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
